A scenario of a person who would search this information and find it helpful is someone involved in a lawsuit that concerns building codes, regulations, and violations. This person may be a defendant, plaintiff, or part of the legal team for either side. They may be seeking an expert witness to provide a professional opinion and conclusion on the case.

The information explains the role and qualifications of an expert witness and how they can be hired by either party or the court. It provides specific examples of the types of qualifications an expert witness should have, such as being a practitioner, instructor, or published author in their field of expertise.

The information also focuses on the role of building inspectors as expert witnesses in cases involving potential building defects, such as structural failures, building distress, or problems with electrical systems. Building inspectors can provide an assessment and opinion on building regulations and violations and can determine if a fixture is in compliance with building regulations.

Furthermore, the information explains the importance of expert witnesses in the analysis of the merits of a case, particularly in identifying latent construction defects that may not be apparent to non-expert witnesses. The expert witness can also make recommendations for how to remedy the defects and potentially save the parties involved the cost of further litigation.

Overall, a person involved in a legal dispute related to building codes and violations, and seeking an expert witness to provide professional opinions and conclusions would find this information helpful.
